data.title: Love the coffee and baked goods
data.text: Best coffee ever.  Lovely service.  And the fresh made french pastries are incredible.  Has the feel of a french cafe in Paris.  No rush, take your time to enjoy.

data.title: Best coffee and croissants
data.text: Real French prepared coffee, quiches, sandwiches and pastries. Plus chocolates. A real cafe in a town full of chains.

data.title: Great place for breakfast
data.text: Took my wife out for Sunday brunch.  I noticed previous reviews were at both extremes, so wanted to make up our own minds.  She had the Tomato with Goat Cheese soup and the Salmon Quiche, I had the Zucchini soup and the Ham and Olive Quiche.  The flavor in both soups were excellent, strong tomato flavor with just a hint of goat cheese.  The zucchini soup was surprising in just how flavorful it was, great creamy consistency, nice use of herbs and spices without overpowering the zucchini.  The Quiches were both full of eggs, nice dense body with a flaky crust.  We had a latte with our meal and ordered a cappuccino with an apple and a pear tart.  Great tasty crust on both with nice filling.  The apple tart was French style with a little sour cream in the filling and a brulee top, very pretty and was a fantastic treat.  Sandrine Gaudin, the proprietor with her husband Ludovic, was very gracious, friendly and attentive to her customers.  Everyone was greeted with a lilty "Bonjour", menus were delivered promptly with the silverware, as soon as we were ready Sandrine was there to take the order, the food was prepared promptly.  This is while there was nearly a full house.  The whole place is small, so is the kitchen, but it is there.  I asked (because of previous reviews) and Sandrine assured me that she and her husband make everything they serve.  The quality of the food was top notch, the service was great and Sandrine makes you feel like you are in her kitchen at home with a friend, not just another customer, except it is a business and we had to pay. ;-)   My wife and I really enjoyed our visit this morning and will be going back.

data.title: A little slice of Paris in Thousand Oaks.
data.text:
I can't tell you how much j'adore this place! I came for a baby shower and then forgot about it for a couple years. I brought my boyfriend here on a day when he was in the mood to go somewhere else. Looking at the menu, we couldn't decide on one things so we got a variety including salad, crepes, sandwich, and cafe mocha (to die for.) Once our order came, we were both in heaven! Everything was soooooooo good. 

We also started chatting with the owner, Sandrine, and we ended up staying for 3 hours! She was so charming and fun to talk to. We cannot wait to return. I am so happy that she is bringing some culture to Thousand Oaks. Give it a try!!

data.title: Breakfast delight
data.text: Great place to go to have breakfast. Meet up with friends for a great cup of coffee and a relaxed time either in the cafe or their outdoor seating area.

data.title: Delightful spot for a light meal and authentic french pastries.
data.text: A French couple owns this place and carries on the traditions of the previous French owners.  It is a delightful, relaxing oasis on a rather nondescript stretch of Thousand Oaks Blvd, but don't let that deter you.  The atmosphere is very pleasant, and the limited seating, which is otherwise unfortunate, keeps the feeling very cozy and low key.  I would imagine that they cater pastries, which would be a great contribution to the town's palette.

data.title: Quaint, cozy, and authentic
data.text: Judge not this cafe by its ordinary storefront cover, but by the quality of the food and service inside, which were outstanding. The soup was homemade and delicious, the salads very fresh and served in a delightful, appetizing presentation, and the baked goods for dessert delectable. Loved it, wish it was closer to home but I do intend to return.

data.title: A great little piece of France in TO!
data.text: This little French Bistro is quaint and the food is freshly prepared and authentic French.  The service is very European (meaning slower), but, they don't hurry you out of the restaurant either.  I go here with my girlfriends every so often and will occasionally pick up some French pastries or desserts.  Their dine in menu is great!  You must come here.

data.title: Mediocre food, bad service
data.text: Food selection is very limited. Quiche was tasteless, crepe and croissant just OK. Coffee was the best part. The owner is very rude. When we walked in she was talking to other customers for a long time without even acknowledging our presence. When she finally turned her attention to us (as we were now her only remaining customers), she was obnoxious. On the positive side, the ambience is nice. It may itself be worth a visit.

data.title: best hot chocolate for MILES
data.text: charming small french cafe with fabulous deserts and the best hot chocolate for MILES around...REAL hot chocolate

data.title: C'est Ci Bon!!
data.text: The best french place around!!  We are so happy that the new management has kept Chocolatine open and has continued to improve on what was already a great place.

data.title: Makes Starbucks Taste Like Sawdust
data.text:
Best. Coffee. Ever.  If you're tired of the burned beans at Starbucks, head to Chocolatine, a quaint, French cafe and soon-to-be bistro that caters to a more sophisticated palate.

Come for the coffee, but stay for an incredible pastry, the lightest, most delicate quiche you've ever had (OMG, have dreams about the Goat Cheese Quiche), a delicious and authentic crepe, or a grilled sandwich.  Then there is the confection counter - sigh, the ruination of my diet.  Cannot leave without at least one macaroon or unique chocolate (strawberry basil, salted caramel, lemon, lavender...you can't go wrong).

And don't forget to chat up the charming French proprietress, Sandrine.  She took over the space with her husband, Ludovic (chef extraordinaire), just over a year ago and has added her own special touch to the decor, the menu, and the whole atmosphere of Chocolatine.  Also new, the shop is now open Mondays and opens earlier during the week (8am).

I'm tempted to keep this place to myself - there are already days when I walk in and find it disappointingly full.  But I cannot deny other T.O. natives the absolute joy of the delicious mocha, quiche, and well, everything else at this amazing spot.

One caution - it can be a bit on the pricey side, especially once you start to peruse the chocolate counter.  But for the wonderful, friendly service, the outstanding food and beverages, and the ambience you'll enjoy, it is well worth the cost.

data.title: Charming and Cozy
data.text:
Never one to miss a chocolate croissant in a 40-mile radius, we decided to try it. It was good, not great, but worth the drive. We also got some cookies and a tart-fruit (I don't remember which kind. 
The best part was speaking French with the pleasant, helpful owner.  We would go back, (maybe earlier in the day the croissants are fresher.)

data.title: Sweetest French Cafe in America
data.text:
As a dual citizen who grew up in France I am always on the lookout for cafes that feel like 'home'.  The new owner is incredibly charming and gracious - we arrived at closing time (note that we thought based on trip advisor hours were 9-6 but she had recently changed them to 8-5) and she served us anyway.  

The cafe au lait was light and frothy,  so beautifully blended that it needed no further addition.  The sandwiches flavorful and perfect in size (and price!)...and the handmade chocolates & pastries superb. 

A lovely light and airy place for a date, tea, or time with a book,  it is a trip to France in both quality,  taste, and atmosphere.  I highly recommend the au lait, lavender macaroons,  and the roast beef sandwich.  

Do note she does close at 5, not 6. 

I look forward to a return trip.

data.title: Double the reason to visit here...
data.text: I posted a review of Choco Cali Bressan in Carpenteria CA. Their chocolate is...well, try them...and if you want to try them, here's a place that is now carrying their chocolates. But before you ruin breakfast or lunch, try the food that this place. Have a ham and cheese sandwich, or the soup of the day. If you speak French, the owner Sandrine, can help you out there. I loved the atmosphere...the Vietnamese and the Europeans, sitting around enjoying a beautiful late morning over strong coffees and pastries and talking in their exotic languages. After you've eaten, get a chocolate...or better yet a box for the love of your life...  In my case, for Dannie on our anniversary.

data.title: Cute little find!
data.text:
We found this little gem as we were driving through TO.  We were a little hungry and I had macaroons on the brain, so I wondered if they had any.......YES!  There is great joy in the land.....and it's dangerous to know they are so close!

We had a light lunch of croque monsieur, ice tea and an espresso.....and for dessert.....you guessed it:  a chocolate and espresso macaroons.

It was a friendly little place.....very mom and pop.  It sounded like from conversations I could hear from other tables that the place had regulars.  The food was really good although a little on the expensive side for a "ham and cheese" sandwich.  But I like supporting "mom and pop" places......

My only small little critique would be the plating of the food.  A little garnish goes a long way to make really good food spectacular!

We will be back!

data.title: great stuff
data.text: best chocolate around . they do not add sugar to whatever their mixture is. the results are delicious . not overly sweet , just right .everything is fresh , with nice little packages for sale or pick your own pieces . my Mom loved them and she knew her chocolate . Hugo is very pleasant as are the rest of the staff . go for the chocolate stay for the coffee.

data.title: A real treat!
data.text: This is one of my favorite places in Thousand Oaks.  A little Parisian cafe with the best hot chocolate and mocha's imagineable.  They have wonderful lunches with fantastic quiche's and treats every day.  This is a great place for lunch, and they have wonderful multi-couse dinners once a month as well.

data.title: Un petit dejuener!
data.text: My favorite place to escape for lunch with my wife. Hugo, the owner is charming and comes out to tell you the specials. You'll hear diners speaking French. The soups and quiches are delicious. His wife makes chocolates, macaroons and eclairs that make me remember Paris.

data.title: French bakery and chocolate shop
data.text: Real treat.  They make chocolates, macaroons, and pastries that are almost as fun to look at as they are to eat.  Good place to have a cup of coffee and indulge in a sweet.  Decent espresso.  I will return and recommend to friends.
